Comparison of Histories

Prof. von Klenze said that a comparison of the histories of Germany,
England, and the United States is a
pertinent preface to a discussion of
conditions prevailing in Germany
today. To one returning after two
years in Germany, America, he said,
presents a dramatic contrast. Assurance and wealth are characteristic
here, while unrest and poverty are
predomenant there.
"Until the World War, England
was the country of success par excellence," the speaker asserted. That
consistent success, he continued, resulted in a rational frame of mind
that anticipated ways out of all difficulties. The same -altitude was
bred in England's American colonists. After the American Civil War,
the investment of the capital of the
victorious North brought general
prosperity exceptin some parts of
the South damaged by the war.

During the past week several
announcements were made concerning the progress of the lacrosse
team. Perhaps the most interesting
of these was the fact that this year,
for the first time, a junior varsity
twelve is to be formed sometime in
the near future. This team will be
composed of those men who have
shown promise at practice, but are
inexperienced or not of varsity
caliber. Those men who have
reached varsity caliber but are
unable to play on the first team for
various reasons will also be eligible
for the junior varsity.
New Style

Dug to the fact that the style of
the game is changing, the coaches
expect to develop two pairs of wing
attack and two pairs of wing defense men. In the past the attack
has confined itself entirely to the
offensive side of the game. If the
plans of the coaches work out, however, the wing attack men will be
able to aid the defense when the
opponents are on the offense. In like
manner the wing defense men will
be expected to support the attack
when threatening the opponents'
goal.

INSIDE INFORMATION ON GLEE CLUB
REVEALED FOR THE FIRST TIME
Soon it will no longer be necessary for instructors, in vain endeavoring to lecture to night classes
in Gilman Hall, to pull down their
windows and stuff rags around them
on Thursday nights. No longer
will the shrill first tenors merge with
the throaty second bases. For soon,
the Johns Hopkins musical club will
culminate their season and further
rehearsals will not be necessary.
Say what you will about the banjo
and mandolin clubs, and the Blue
Jays; the Glee Club composes the
Musical Club. With its membership
of perhaps sixty it is estimated that
if only one-half of this number
inveighed a friend, relative or girl
into coming to the performance the
average size church hall where the
performance is usually given would
be filled to capacity.
During the first part of the season
concerts are given in the wilds of
Walbrook where the customary audience of the doorkeeper, the head
of the local young peoples union,
and five girls brought by club members, listen to the first tryout. In
these, the songs are sung with the
aid of music sheets. By the time of
the Zion Church concert only half
of the members find it necessary to
use the sheets and by the time of the
home concert the performance has
reached its utmost perfection.
